Kevin
.
The Sporting threat is believed to have gone away.
Final details on the deal are being sorted between all sides.
Kevin has already done a medical, and Samuel Chukwueze and Tyrique George are set to follow.

live_updates.title: Wilson staying at Fulham
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' James Cole:
Harry Wilson
is staying at
Fulham.
Leeds United were talks over the signing as they looked to bring in the forward, but the move did not go through.
Wilson is with the Wales squad in Cardiff and preparing for their World Cup qualifier against Kazakhstan on Thursday.

live_updates.title: Fulham complete Chukwueze loan signing
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Fulham
have signed
Samuel Chukwueze
from
AC Milan
on loan for the season, with an option to make the move permanent.
A Nigeria international alongside Alex Iwobi and Calvin Bassey, Chukwueze will wear the number 19 shirt.
Speaking to the
club's media
, the 26-year-old said: “I’m so happy to be here. It’s an amazing club. It feels like home, because I have my people around me.
“I feel at home already, and I can’t wait to get started.”

live_updates.title: George to Fulham not done in time
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' James Cole:
Fulham's
attempted deal to sign
Chelsea
forward
Tyrique George
did not go through.
It was set to be a permanent deal worth £22m after a five-year contract had been agreed.

live_updates.title: Why Wilson's move to Leeds fell through
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Zinny Boswell:
Fulham
pulled the plug on
Harry Wilson's
Deadline Day move to
Leeds
at the very last minute,
Sky Sports News
understands.
Leeds and Wilson had signed a deal sheet in the hope of finalising a move.
However, it is understood Fulham did not to sign the paperwork required for the Premier League to grant an additional two hours to get the transfer over the line.
Fulham insist they were clear that Wilson was not for sale, while Leeds feel they were encouraged to increase their offer for the Wales international on Deadline Day.
Leeds were first made aware of Wilson's potential availability over the weekend as Fulham pursued the signings of Kevin and Samuel Chukwueze.
Wilson was keen on the move as his opportunities were already limited at Fulham and both players will be directly competing with him for minutes, only decreasing his chances of playing.
Although there is frustration over missing out on Wilson, Leeds are understood to be very happy with their business this summer.
The priority for the window was strengthening the spine of Daniel Farke's team for the Premier League return - and they managed to do that with plenty of time to spare by bringing in the likes of Anton Stach, Jaka Bijol and Lucas Perri.
Leeds have backed Farke to the tune of more than £100m this summer with 10 new additions.

live_updates.title: Fulham sign Kevin for club-record deal
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Fulham
have confirmed the signing of
Kevin
for a club-record deal of £34.6m (€40m).
The winger joins from
Shakhtar Donetsk
and has agreed a five-year deal.
Sporting showed late interest in Kevin, but the Premier League club fended off the Portuguese side.
He told the club's media: “I am happy to be in the biggest league in the world, at a huge club, too. I’m very flattered for everything that’s happening in my life, and I hope to score a lot of goals this season and do great work here in Fulham.”

live_updates.title: Fulham's Kusi-Asare deal went through in time
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Fulham's
deal to sign
Bayern Munich
striker
Johan Kusi-Asare
went through in time.
The west London club explored a loan but would only go ahead if there was an option to make it a permanent deal at the end of the loan period.
A formal announcement is expected at some point today.

live_updates.title: Fulham confirm Kusi-Asare signing
live_updates.author: Patrick Rowe
live_updates.text:
Fulham
have confirmed the signing of
Bayern Munich
striker
Johan Kusi-Asare
on loan with an option to make the move permanent.
Sky Sports News
understands the west London club explored a loan but would only go ahead if there was an option to make it a permanent deal at the end of the loan period.
Speaking in a statement released by the club, Kusi-Asare said: “I’m really excited to join Fulham. It’s a fantastic club with great supporters, and I can’t wait to get started, work with my teammates and give everything for the club.”

live_updates.title: Fulham confirm Kusi-Asare signing
live_updates.author: Patrick Rowe
live_updates.text:
Fulham
have confirmed the signing of
Bayern Munich
striker
Jonah Kusi-Asare
on loan with an option to make the move permanent.
Sky Sports News
understands the west London club explored a loan but would only go ahead if there was an option to make it a permanent deal at the end of the loan period.
Speaking in a statement released by the club, Kusi-Asare said: “I’m really excited to join Fulham. It’s a fantastic club with great supporters, and I can’t wait to get started, work with my teammates and give everything for the club.”

live_updates.title: Fulham's Kusi-Asare deal went through in time
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Fulham's
deal to sign
Bayern Munich
striker
Jonah Kusi-Asare
went through in time.
The west London club explored a loan but would only go ahead if there was an option to make it a permanent deal at the end of the loan period.
A formal announcement is expected at some point today.

live_updates.title: Cambridge tie live on Sky Sports+ on September 23
live_updates.author: Tony Tighe
live_updates.text:
Fulham's
Carabao Cup third-round tie against
Cambridge United
will take place on Tuesday September 23, kicking off at 7.45pm, live on
Sky Sports+
.
Their Premier League games either side of the tie, at home to
Brentford
on Saturday September 20 and away to
Aston Villa
on Saturday September 27, are not impacted.

live_updates.title: Abdallah Sima joins Lens
live_updates.author: Dominic Ball
live_updates.text:
Brighton
striker
Abdallah Sima
has joined Ligue 1 club
Lens
in a deal worth £4m plus add-ons.
The forward, who never made a Premier League appearance for the Premier League side after joining in 2021, has had loan spells at Stoke, Angers, Rangers and Stade Brestois.
Brighton are working on trimming their squad ahead of Monday's deadline.
Facundo Buonanotte
could depart to Chelsea with talks ongoing between the west London club and Brighton.
Jeremy Sarmiento
may also leave while Tariq Lamptey is attracting interest.

live_updates.title: Brighton's Enciso edging closer to Strasbourg move
live_updates.author: Dominic Ball
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Elliot Cook:
Chelsea's
owners BlueCo are edging closer to completing a deal with
Brighton
for
Julio Enciso
to join
Strasbourg
.
The 21-year-old is being offered a five-year contract.
It is expected the transfer will be completed before the window closes on Monday.
Sky Sports News
reported on Thursday that Enciso had returned to Brighton to continue his rehab on a knee injury.
The Paraguay international will initially move to BlueCo-owned Strasbourg.
Enciso is not part of Fabian Hurzeler's plans this season and spent the second half of last season on loan at Ipswich.

live_updates.title: Chelsea close to completing loan signing of Brighton's Buonanotte
live_updates.author: Dominic Ball
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Elliot Cook and Mark McAdam:
Chelsea
are close to completing the loan signing of
Brighton
attacking midfielder
Facundo Buonanotte
.
The deal under discussion does not include an option or an obligation to buy - it is a season-long loan.
There was interest in the 20-year-old from other Premier League clubs, including
Leeds United
.
Brighton only wanted to loan the Argentina international to a club in England.
Borussia Dortmund
had made a loan offer for the player with an option, while there was also interest from French outfit
Lyon
.

live_updates.title: Cremonese reach agreement for Sarmiento
live_updates.author: David Richardson
live_updates.text:
Cremonese
have reached an agreement with
Brighton
for the signing of winger
Jeremy Sarmiento
, according to
Sky in Italy.
The deal is for a loan with an option to buy, which could become an obligation if the Italian club avoid relegation from Serie A.
Sarmiento has two years left on his current deal at Brighton.

live_updates.title: Fiorentina agree Lamptey deal
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News'  Mark McAdam and Elliot Cook:
Fiorentina
have agreed a deal with
Brighton
for the signing of
Tariq Lamptey.
The transfer is worth up to £6m including add-ons.
Lamptey still needs to take a medical and finalise terms with the Italian club before the move goes through.

live_updates.title: Hurzeler: Football is not always about tactics
live_updates.author: David Richardson
live_updates.text:
Brighton
boss
Fabian Hurzeler
claimed "football is not always about tactics" after his side came back to beat Manchester City.
Hurzeler made a quadruple substitution in the 61st minute which saw James Milner cancel out Erling Haaland's opener before Brajan Gruda netted a late winner.
"Football is not always about tactics, it is sometimes about energy and the energy you put on the pitch. We showed it today. In the second half, we had this energy," he said.
"This can win you games. We didn't believe in ourselves [before the substitutes]. I decided to make the four changes. It is always a decision we make together."

live_updates.title: Brighton super subs inflict another defeat on Man City
live_updates.author: David Richardson
live_updates.text: Manchester City suffered their second defeat from their opening three Premier League games after collapsing to a late 2-1 loss at Brighton.

live_updates.title: Brighton's O'Riley set for Marseille medical
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Lyall Thomas:
Brighton
’s
Matt O’Riley
is understood to be travelling to France this morning for a medical with
Marseille
.
The midfielder is set to join them on a straight loan with no option to make the deal permanent.
O'Riley was left on the bench yesterday as Brighton beat Manchester City.
Marseille are managed by former Brighton head coach
Roberto de Zerbi
.

live_updates.title: Palace close to signing Brighton's Igor
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Rob Dorsett:
Crystal Palace
are close to an agreement with
Brighton
over a loan deal for defender
Igor Julio
.
Sky Sports News
has been told the deal includes an option for Palace to buy him at the end of the season.
Plans are in place for Igor to travel to South London for a medical later today.
West Ham
held an interest in the player, but Palace now looks his more likely destination.

live_updates.title: Lamptey joins Fiorentina on permanent deal
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Mark McAdam and Elliot Cook:
Brighton
have announced right-back
Tariq Lamptey
has joined
Fiorentina
on a permanent deal.
The 24-year-old is moving to Serie A in a deal worth up to £6m including add-ons.
Sky Sports News
reported on Saturday that an agreement had been reached between the two clubs.
Lamptey signed a one-year contract extension at Brighton in June but selling the player now means the Premier League club will receive a fee, instead of losing him for nothing.

live_updates.title: Brighton's O'Riley set for Marseille medical
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Lyall Thomas:
Matt O'Riley
has arrived in
Marseille
ahead of his loan move from
Brighton
.
The Denmark international has been pictured with fans outside Marseille's training ground.
The midfielder is set to join them on a straight loan with no option to make the deal permanent.
O'Riley was left on the bench yesterday as Brighton beat Manchester City.
Marseille are managed by former Brighton head coach
Roberto de Zerbi
.

live_updates.title: More Brighton exits expected
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News reporter Chris Nightingale:
Brighton
have let a lot of players go this summer and that number is only going to increase throughout Deadline Day with updates on
Julio Enciso, Facundo Buonanotte, Jeremy Sarmiento
and
Matt O’Riley
still to come.
Manager Fabian Hurzeler has spoken about the need to trim his squad throughout this window, but it’s easy to see some areas could become light with injury.

live_updates.title: Enciso joins Strasbourg
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Elliot Cook:
Brighton
attacking midfielder
Julio Enciso
has completed his move to French club
Strasbourg
.
The 21-year-old has joined on a permanent deal for a fee understood to be £10m.
Brighton have a sell-on clause as part of the deal.
Enciso is the second player who has left the club today after
Tariq Lamptey
joined Fiorentina.

live_updates.title: Buonanotte moves to Chelsea on loan
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Brighton
attacking midfielder
Facundo Buonanotte
has joined
Chelsea
on a season-long loan.
There is no option or obligation to buy.
There was strong interest from other Premier League clubs including Leeds.
The Argentina international, who prefers to play in the No 10 position, has become the latest Brighton player to move to Chelsea.
Sky Sports News
reported on Friday that Chelsea were close to completing the deal.
Brighton head coach
Fabian Hurzeler
said: “This is a great opportunity for Facundo to play regular Premier League and Champions League football this season and further his development.
“Facundo has great potential and we see his long-term future with us here, and we will be monitoring his progress."

live_updates.title: Brighton make Gomez enquiry
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Rob Dorsett and Vinny O'Connor:
Brighton & Hove Albion made an enquiry to take Joe Gomez on loan for the season, but were unable to reach an agreement with Liverpool over how his wages would be split between the two clubs.
Liverpool were unwilling to sanction a loan move, having already rejected a number of enquiries for the defender. AC Milan also explored a deal earlier in the window, but there was not enough time to complete the transfer once Marc Guehi’s move to Anfield became the focus.
As a result, Gomez will be staying at Liverpool this summer, even if Guehi completes his switch.

live_updates.title: Julio not joining Palace - as things stand
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Rob Dorsett:
Igor Julio
is not going to join
Crystal Palace
as things stand, despite completing a medical there this afternoon -
West Ham
are now in talks with
Brighton
and the player to try to complete a deal to take him on loan.
Palace were adamant that they would only allow Marc Guehi to leave for Liverpool once they had a replacement in. That replacement was Igor.
Sky Sports News
has been told Palace have
NOT
called Guehi back from his medical with Liverpool in London - instead, they are now looking at alternative options to fill their centre back void.

live_updates.title: Julio not joining Palace - as things stand
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Rob Dorsett, Chris Reidy and James Savundra:
Igor Julio
is on his way from
Crystal Palace
to
West Ham
after deciding against a move to Selhurst Park.
The Brighton defender is not joining Palace despite completing a medical there this afternoon.
West Ham
are now in talks with
Brighton
and the player to try to complete a deal to take him on loan.
Palace were adamant they would only allow
Marc Guehi
to leave for Liverpool once they had a replacement in. That replacement was Igor.
Sky Sports News
has been told Palace have
NOT
called Guehi back from his medical with Liverpool in London.
It is understood Igor had concerns about his potential playing time at Palace as they are also looking to sign other central defenders.

live_updates.title: West Ham announce Julio loan signing
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
West Ham
have announced the signing defender
Igor Julio
on a season-long loan from Brighton.
The 27-year-old had been set to join Crystal Palace, even undertaking a medical, but decided to join the Hammers instead.
It is understood that Julio had concerns about his potential playing time at Crystal Palace. It ultimately curtailed
Marc Guehi's proposed move to Liverpool.
“I am really happy to be here at West Ham United,” Julio told the
club's media.
“It is a big club, an historic club, with fantastic support and a special identity.
“I saw this in Prague during the Conference League final two years ago, and I feel very proud to now be representing the colours.
“The project here is very exciting – there are many good players at the club and I know that there is a very positive environment in the dressing room that it will be great to be a part of.
“I am ready for the challenge and looking forward to giving everything I can to help the team and the club.”

live_updates.title: Buonanotte moves to Chelsea on loan
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Brighton
attacking midfielder
Facundo Buonanotte
has joined
Chelsea
on a season-long loan.
There is no option or obligation to buy.
There was strong interest from other Premier League clubs including Leeds.
The Argentina international, who prefers to play in the No 10 position, has become the latest Brighton player to move to Chelsea.
Sky Sports News
reported on Friday that Chelsea were close to completing the deal.
Brighton head coach
Fabian Hurzeler
said: “This is a great opportunity for Facundo to play regular Premier League and Champions League football this season and further his development.
“Facundo has great potential and we see his long-term future with us here, and we will be monitoring his progress."

live_updates.title: Marseille sign O'Riley on loan - but he still has Brighton future
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Marseille
have completed the season-long loan signing of
Brighton
midfielder
Matt O'Riley
.
The deal for the Denmark international is a straight loan with no option.
Seagulls head coach
Fabian Hurzeler
said: "Matt has the opportunity to challenge himself at the highest level in France and in the Champions League.
"We have a lot of competition in the midfield positions, and while we see Matt's long-term future here with us, this gives him the potential of more game time.
"We will monitor his progress throughout the season with Marseille, and we wish him well for the rest of the season."

live_updates.title: Barnsley tie on Sky Sports+ on September 23
live_updates.author: Nick Wright
live_updates.text:
Brighton's
Carabao Cup third round tie away to
Barnsley
will take place on September 23, live on
Sky Sports+
and kicking off at 7.45pm.
Their Premier League games either side of the tie, at home to
Tottenham
on Saturday September 20 and away to
Chelsea
on September 27, are not impacted.

live_updates.title: Good morning!
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
With the summer transfer window having closed last night, it's time for a look at last weekend's Premier League action in Ref Watch!
Former Premier League referee Dermot Gallagher is in the studio ready to analyse, so stay tuned!

live_updates.title: Stamford Bridge controversy on the agenda!
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
First up this morning will be Saturday's stormy west London derby between
Chelsea
and
Fulham
at Stamford Bridge that saw the VAR in the spotlight for an "unbelievable" decision to rule out Josh King's Fulham opener - let's see what Dermot has to say about that huge call when he is on set shortly:

live_updates.title: Should Man Utd have been awarded a penalty in Burnley win?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
Dermot will also be quizzed on
Man Ut'd
five-goal thriller with Burnley at Old Trafford on Saturday that saw the Red Devils claim a vital three points, but should their winning penalty have been given?

live_updates.title: Stamford Bridge controversy on the agenda!
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
First up this morning will be Saturday's stormy west London derby between
Chelsea
and
Fulham
at Stamford Bridge that saw the VAR in the spotlight for an "unbelievable" decision to rule out Josh King's Fulham opener - let's see what Dermot has to say about that huge call when he is on set shortly:

live_updates.title: Should King's derby goal have been ruled out?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Josh King's goal is ruled out after a VAR review, with Rodrigo Muniz adjudged to have fouled Trevoh Chalobah in the build-up with what PGMOL called a "careless challenge".
DERMOT SAYS
: "I think he's been too forensic. He's looked and looked and I'm convinced the more you look at something, the more you talk yourself into it.
"The game just goes on, everybody carries on.
"I was watching it live and the referee has got the best view. If you run it again, he's six, seven, eight yards from it. He's got a direct view of it. He turns away, he makes no decision whatsoever.
"I've been looking at that since Saturday morning and I can't understand what he thinks he saw.
"You only have to see it once to see it's a skilful turn by the player. It's just not a foul."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That is not careless at all. Anyone that knows football can see Muniz is trying to drag the ball and drag it again. But because Chalobah's foot is there, underneath Muniz's foot, he's stepped on him, but it's never a foul. It's a terrible decision and it stopped King for scoring a great goal.
"When you look at the players, no one appealed for a foul because it wasn't."

live_updates.title: Should King's derby goal have been ruled out?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Josh King's goal is ruled out after a VAR review, with Rodrigo Muniz adjudged to have fouled Trevoh Chalobah in the build-up with what PGMOL called a "careless challenge".
DERMOT SAYS
: "I think he's been too forensic. He's looked and looked and I'm convinced the more you look at something, the more you talk yourself into it.
"The game just goes on, everybody carries on.
"I was watching it live and the referee has got the best view. If you run it again, he's six, seven, eight yards from it. He's got a direct view of it. He turns away, he makes no decision whatsoever.
"I've been looking at that since Saturday morning and I can't understand what he thinks he saw.
"You only have to see it once to see it's a skilful turn by the player. It's just not a foul."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That is not careless at all. Anyone that knows football can see Muniz is trying to drag the ball and drag it again.
"But because Chalobah's foot is there, underneath Muniz's foot, he's stepped on him, but it's never a foul. It's a terrible decision and it stopped King for scoring a great goal.
"When you look at the players, no one appealed for a foul because it wasn't."

live_updates.title: Should Chelsea's opener have stood?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea open the scoring just before half-time, but Joao Pedro's opener comes in the ninth minute of first-half injury time when only eight were scheduled.
DERMOT SAYS
: Rob Jones will know that, but what i will say is, it does not matter how long you play as a referee, as long as the score does not change in that time [injury time] - that always comes back to bite the referee, but he felt there was enough time to play. It is his decision...

live_updates.title: Correct call to award Chelsea a penalty?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea were awarded a penalty after Ryan Sessegnon raised his arms and blocked Trevoh Chalobah's ball into the box.
DERMOT SAYS
: "They are always going to be given. We see it week in, week out. Any player that has got his arm up and out like that is going to be punished.
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "You can't really challenge like that anymore. His arms are out, in an unnatural position.
"Last week, we spoke about Dewsbury-Hall's one and I think that was harsh as his arm was close to him.
"With this one, when you've got your arms up like this, it's going to be a penalty and it should."

live_updates.title: Correct call to award Chelsea a penalty?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea were awarded a penalty after Ryan Sessegnon raised his arms and blocked Trevoh Chalobah's ball into the box.
DERMOT SAYS
: "They are always going to be given. We see it week in, week out. Any player that has got his arm up and out like that is going to be punished.
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "You can't really challenge like that anymore. His arms are out, in an unnatural position.
"Last week, we spoke about Dewsbury-Hall's one and I think that was harsh as his arm was close to him.
"With this one, when you've got your arms up like this, it's going to be a penalty and it should be."

live_updates.title: Were Man Utd fortuante to be awarded a late penalty vs Burnley?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd were awarded a late penalty against Burnley for "sustained pulling" on Amad Diallo.
DERMOT SAYS
: The shirt was dragged off his back, there is no doubt about it, it starts outside the penalty area and continues on the line, which belongs to the goalkeeper and so it is a penalty.
It is common practice now [for players to then dive after an initial shirt pull], it is what players do - it is a foul, there is no doubt about that. It starts outside the box, which is why Sam [Barrott] gives a free kick - but when you see it, it is inside the penalty area, there is no doubt about it.
[VAR] Stuart Atwell has quite rightly alerted him, sent him to the screen- penalty.

live_updates.title: Should Mount's penalty have been overturned?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd's Mason Mount earned a penalty after a tangle with Burnley's Kyle Walker in the box, but the decision was overturned after a VAR review
DERMOT SAYS
:"I actually think it's a foul, but I don't think it's a penalty - I think it's a foul outside the penalty area.
"It's different to a shirt-pull. If you pull somebody down like that, it's a foul. With a shirt-pull, it can continue into the penalty area.
"If they are not going to give Mason Mount a penalty, I think it should be a free-kick, but they actually gave no foul and free-kick to the goalkeeper."

live_updates.title: Should Mount's penalty have been overturned?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd's Mason Mount earned a penalty after a tangle with Burnley's Kyle Walker in the box, but the decision was overturned after a VAR review
DERMOT SAYS
:"I actually think it's a foul, but I don't think it's a penalty - I think it's a foul outside the penalty area.
"It's different to a shirt-pull. If you pull somebody down like that, it's a foul. With a shirt-pull, it can continue into the penalty area.
"If they are not going to give Mason Mount a penalty, I think it should be a free-kick, but they actually gave no foul and free-kick to the goalkeeper."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "I thought it was a free-kick outside the box, but it was definitely for Mason Mount.
"Walker's arm is around his back, there's a collision and he's fallen on him. That's definitely a foul, all day long.
"I can't believe the ref hasn't seen that."

live_updates.title: Kamada's penalty 'one of the most obvious calls'
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Crystal Palace win a penalty when Daichi Kamada is tripped by Aston Villa goalkeeper Marco Bizot.
DERMOT SAYS
: "No complaints. Penalty and yellow card for the goalkeeper. He made a reckless challenge."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That's one of the most obvious ones we've seen this weekend."

live_updates.title: Should Foster's strike have stood at Old Trafford?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Burnley striker Lyle Foster has a goal ruled out for offside after a very close call, but were the right lines drawn by the VAR?
DERMOT SAYS
: We have moved forward, originally we did not see anything, now we are seeing something. Everything goes forward, but this one we are talking about for two reasons: 1) It is so tight, it must be right on the margins and 2) the wrong graphic was initially shown.
People forget one thing, though - the original decision was offside, the assistant gave it offside on the field. People can argue all day long about VAR, but even without VAR, that goal would have been disallowed.

live_updates.title: Kamada's penalty 'one of the most obvious calls'
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Crystal Palace win a penalty when Daichi Kamada is tripped by Aston Villa goalkeeper Marco Bizot.
DERMOT SAYS
: "No complaints. Penalty and yellow card for the goalkeeper. He made a reckless challenge."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That's one of the most obvious ones we've seen this weekend."

live_updates.title: Was Cash's tackle on Kamada worthy of a red?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Aston Villa's Matty Cash is shown a yellow card for a late tackle on Daichi Kamada.
DERMOT SAYS
: "He comes in, he's low, it's a foul - there's no doubt about that. It's not a nice foul, but he's low.
"He doesn't come a long way either. It's also a sideways challenge, so it doesn't have that massive impact and danger that one head-on has."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "If Matty Cash's leg was straight out, then there would be a case it could be a red card.
"The fact he's not out of control, he's stretching for a ball and his foot is on his ankle, I definitely wouldn't give a red."

live_updates.title: Should King's derby goal have been ruled out?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Josh King's goal is ruled out after a VAR review, with Rodrigo Muniz adjudged to have fouled Trevoh Chalobah in the build-up with what PGMOL called a "careless challenge".
DERMOT SAYS
: "I think he's been too forensic. He's looked and looked and I'm convinced the more you look at something, the more you talk yourself into it.
"The game just goes on, everybody carries on.
"I was watching it live and the referee has got the best view. If you run it again, he's six, seven, eight yards from it. He's got a direct view of it. He turns away, he makes no decision whatsoever.
"I've been looking at that since Saturday morning and I can't understand what he thinks he saw.
"You only have to see it once to see it's a skilful turn by the player. It's just not a foul."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That is not careless at all. Anyone that knows football can see Muniz is trying to drag the ball and drag it again.
"But because Chalobah's foot is there, underneath Muniz's foot, he's stepped on him, but it's never a foul. It's a terrible decision and it stopped King for scoring a great goal.
"When you look at the players, no one appealed for a foul because it wasn't."

live_updates.title: Could Semenyo have been sent off at Tottenham?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Bournemouth forward Antoine Semenyo is not sent off, despite being on a yellow card and bringing down Tottenham forward Richarlison on the halfway line.
DERMOT SAYS
: He is lucky he has got [Alex] Scott there as a defender as it is not stopping a promising attack - he has four covering defenders, Scott is the first one there.
It is a foul, there is no doubt about that, but is it a foul to send him off? I do not think so.

live_updates.title: 'Uproar if pen given against Szoboszlai'
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT:
A long throw from Arsenal hit the top of the arm of Liverpool's Dominik Szoboszlai. No penalty is awarded.
DERMOT SAYS
: "Everybody would've been aghast if a penalty was given for that.
"A, it's at the top of his arm. B, it's come over the top of his head. His arms are in position you'd expect them to be at that point."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That's a ridiculous decision if he gives that! If he'dhave given that, there would have been uproar."

live_updates.title: Was Brentford's penalty award the correct call?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Brentford are awarded a penalty after Reinildo pulls down Nathan Collins from a corner.
DERMOT SAYS
: Wheh I watched the briefing earlier this season, this was the one they were trying to eliminate. You are
never going to get them all, but the player never once looks at the ball at all...

live_updates.title: Was Brentford's penalty award the correct call?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Brentford are awarded a penalty after Reinildo pulls down Nathan Collins from a corner.
DERMOT SAYS
: Wheh I watched the briefing earlier this season, this was the one they were trying to eliminate. You are
never going to get them all, but the player never once looks at the ball at all.
It is a deterrent, and if you give them, players will stop doing it and that is what we want.

live_updates.title: Good morning!
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
With the summer transfer window having closed last night, it's time for a look at last weekend's Premier League action in Ref Watch!
Former Premier League referee Dermot Gallagher is in the studio ready to analyse, so stay tuned!

live_updates.title: Should Man Utd have been awarded a penalty in Burnley win?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
Dermot will also be quizzed on
Man Ut'd
five-goal thriller with Burnley at Old Trafford on Saturday that saw the Red Devils claim a vital three points, but should their winning penalty have been given?

live_updates.title: Stamford Bridge controversy on the agenda!
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
First up this morning will be Saturday's stormy west London derby between
Chelsea
and
Fulham
at Stamford Bridge that saw the VAR in the spotlight for an "unbelievable" decision to rule out Josh King's Fulham opener - let's see what Dermot has to say about that huge call when he is on set shortly:

live_updates.title: Should King's derby goal have been ruled out?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Josh King's goal is ruled out after a VAR review, with Rodrigo Muniz adjudged to have fouled Trevoh Chalobah in the build-up with what PGMOL called a "careless challenge".
DERMOT SAYS

"I was watching it live and the referee has got the best view. If you run it again, he's six, seven, eight yards from it. He's got a direct view of it. He turns away, he makes no decision whatsoever.
"I've been looking at that since Saturday morning and I can't understand what he thinks he saw.
"You only have to see it once to see it's a skilful turn by the player. It's just not a foul."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "That is not careless at all. Anyone that knows football can see Muniz is trying to drag the ball and drag it again.

"When you look at the players, no one appealed for a foul because it wasn't."

live_updates.title: Should Chelsea's opener have stood?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea open the scoring just before half-time, but Joao Pedro's opener comes in the ninth minute of first-half injury time when only eight were scheduled.
DERMOT SAYS
: Rob Jones will know that, but what i will say is, it does not matter how long you play as a referee, as long as the score does not change in that time [injury time] - that always comes back to bite the referee, but he felt there was enough time to play. It is his decision...

live_updates.title: Correct call to award Chelsea a penalty?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea were awarded a penalty after Ryan Sessegnon raised his arms and blocked Trevoh Chalobah's ball into the box.
DERMOT SAYS
: "They are always going to be given. We see it week in, week out. Any player that has got his arm up and out like that is going to be punished.
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "You can't really challenge like that anymore. His arms are out, in an unnatural position.
"Last week, we spoke about Dewsbury-Hall's one and I think that was harsh as his arm was close to him.
"With this one, when you've got your arms up like this, it's going to be a penalty and it should."

live_updates.title: Correct call to award Chelsea a penalty?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Chelsea were awarded a penalty after Ryan Sessegnon raised his arms and blocked Trevoh Chalobah's ball into the box.
DERMOT SAYS

"With this one, when you've got your arms up like this, it's going to be a penalty and it should be."

live_updates.title: Were Man Utd fortuante to be awarded a late penalty vs Burnley?
live_updates.author: Richard Morgan
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd were awarded a late penalty against Burnley for "sustained pulling" on Amad Diallo.
DERMOT SAYS
: The shirt was dragged off his back, there is no doubt about it, it starts outside the penalty area and continues on the line, which belongs to the goalkeeper and so it is a penalty.
It is common practice now [for players to then dive after an initial shirt pull], it is what players do - it is a foul, there is no doubt about that. It starts outside the box, which is why Sam [Barrott] gives a free kick - but when you see it, it is inside the penalty area, there is no doubt about it.
[VAR] Stuart Atwell has quite rightly alerted him, sent him to the screen- penalty.

live_updates.title: Should Mount's penalty have been overturned?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd's Mason Mount earned a penalty after a tangle with Burnley's Kyle Walker in the box, but the decision was overturned after a VAR review
DERMOT SAYS
:"I actually think it's a foul, but I don't think it's a penalty - I think it's a foul outside the penalty area.
"It's different to a shirt-pull. If you pull somebody down like that, it's a foul. With a shirt-pull, it can continue into the penalty area.
"If they are not going to give Mason Mount a penalty, I think it should be a free-kick, but they actually gave no foul and free-kick to the goalkeeper."

live_updates.title: Should Mount's penalty have been overturned?
live_updates.author: Dan Long
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Man Utd's Mason Mount earned a penalty after a tangle with Burnley's Kyle Walker in the box, but the decision was overturned after a VAR review
DERMOT SAYS
:"I actually think it's a foul, but I don't think it's a penalty - I think it's a foul outside the penalty area.

"If they are not going to give Mason Mount a penalty, I think it should be a free-kick, but they actually gave no foul and free-kick to the goalkeeper."
JAY BOTHROYD SAYS
: "I thought it was a free-kick outside the box, but it was definitely for Mason Mount.
"Walker's arm is around his back, there's a collision and he's fallen on him. That's definitely a foul, all day long.
"I can't believe the ref hasn't seen that."

live_updates.title: Former captain Brownhill considers huge Saudi offer
live_updates.author: Patrick Rowe
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' James Savundra:
Former
Burnley
midfielder
Josh Brownhill
is considering a huge offer from Saudi Pro League club
Al Shabab
.
Brownhill has held lengthy discussions with head coach Imanol Alguacil regarding a potential move to the Saudi Arabian side.
The club - recently managed by Wolves boss
Vitor Pereira
- are looking to add Brownhill to their ranks as they bid for a title push this season.
It is believed that Al Shabab are willing to offer Brownhill a salary of more than £100,000 a week.
Since deciding to bring to an end to his time at Burnley - having turned down a new contract - the 29-year-old has had interest from the Premier League and Championship.
Brownhill was named in the PFA Championship team of the year last week after scoring 18 goals from midfield in Burnley’s promotion campaign.
The former Clarets captain is thought to be relaxed about his next steps as he is arguably one of the most attractive free agents in the market and can sign outside of the transfer window.

live_updates.title: Burnley show interest in Florentino
live_updates.author: Laura Hunter
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Italy's Luca Bendoni and Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Burnley
are interested in Benfica midfielder
Florentino Luis.
Marseille and Roma have also shown interest in him this summer.
Burnley are still looking to strengthen in four positions, but their preference is to bring players in on loan or on free transfers.
The positions they are still looking at are centre-back, right-back, central-midfield and striker.

live_updates.title: Parker: We go to Man Utd with full belief against a wounded animal in an uncomfortable place
live_updates.author: William Bitibiri
live_updates.text:
Burnley
boss
Scott Parker
says his side will take full belief to Old Trafford as they take on a
Manchester United
side in an uncomfortable place.
The Clarets make the trip to Old Trafford to face a United side fresh of a humiliating Carabao Cup exit at the hands of League Two Grimsby Town.
United were beaten on penalties after leaving it late to claw back a two-goal deficit at Blundell Park.
Asked about the prospect of facing United, Parker said:
"There’s noise around every club. The noise can sometimes be blown u,p and sometimes that narrative can be set by anything it needs to be set by, and the magnitude can make things bigger.
"There’s no doubt at this present moment in time that Man Utd and Amorim are in a place that is uncomfortable for them, but we are playing against a world-class team on their day, it’s a team that can cause you problems.
"They’ve got exceptional players and ones that can change a game at any moment.
"The ups and downs and the bumps of football bring different results sometimes. But we are under no illusions about the task we have ahead of us.
"We go in there with full belief that we can perform to our level, to what we need to be to get a result. I don’t really look into whether it’s good moments or bad moments.
"There are flip sides to it. You can look at one side of it and say it’s a bit of a wounded animal with world-class players that can obviously have a reaction. On the other side, there may be a bit of edginess. Fundamentally, we’ll try to give our best version."

live_updates.title: Burnley agree deal for Benfica's Luis
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth and Luca Bendo
Burnley
have agreed a deal in principle with
Benfica
for midfielder
Florentino Luis
.
The deal is a loan plus an obligation to buy, with the total fee believed to be worth £21.6m (€25m).
There is still work to do as no agreement on the player side yet.

live_updates.title: Parker unsure if it's a good time to face crisis-hit Man Utd
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Burnley
boss
Scott Parker
does not know whether it is a good time to play
Manchester United.
United have been flung into an early-season crisis after their  Carabao Cup exit to Grimsby on Wednesday, which comes on the back of a two-game winless start to the Premier League season.
The Clarets go to Old Trafford on Saturday where they could either face a reaction or take advantage of some nerves.
“There’s always noise around every team. I understand that, sometimes that noise can be blown up,” Parker said.
“There’s no doubt that Man Utd are in a place that is an uncomfortable place.
“The ups and downs and the bumps of football sometimes bring different results, of course. But we’re under no illusions of the task we have ahead of us at the weekend.
“I don’t really look into whether it’s a good or a bad time to go there. There’s always flip sides to that. You can look at one side of it and say, it’s a bit of a wounded animal with world-class players that can obviously have a reaction.
“On the other side, of course, there may be a bit of edginess, but fundamentally, we’ll try and give our best version and take on the task of going to play Manchester United at Old Trafford.”

live_updates.title: Report: Fernandes rescues Man Utd as they scrape past Burnley
live_updates.author: William Bitibiri
live_updates.text:
Bruno Fernandes
scored a dramatic 96th-minute penalty as
Manchester United
scraped past
Burnley
3-2 in a game that
Ruben Amorim
had called a "must win".

live_updates.title: Parker: VAR is making football sterile
live_updates.author: Lewis Jones
live_updates.text:
Scott Parker on the intervention of VAR to award the decisive spot-kick for a tug by Jaidon Anthony on Amad Diallo in Burnley's defeat at Manchester United:
"It's the way the game is going. It's going to become the most sterile game there is. We're probably months or a year away from not celebrating goals.
"I stand on the touchline, you score a goal and I feel like there's a million things go through your mind, a checklist, was it offside? Did he step on his toe two minutes before? We need to get a computer out."

live_updates.title: Benfica's Luis having Burnley medical
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Florentino Luis
is having medical in Manchester this morning ahead of loan move from
Benfica to Burnley.
All the other details on the move have been agreed for the Portugal midfielder.
Burnley are now focusing on outgoings this Deadline Day.

live_updates.title: Burnley pair set to depart on loan
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Burnley
duo
Aaron Ramsey
and
Michael Obafemi
are likely to leave on loan today.
Ramsey is set to join
Leicester
, while Obafemi is expected to sign for German side
VFL Bochum
.

live_updates.title: Burnley pair set to depart on loan
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Dharmesh Sheth:
Burnley
duo

and

are likely to leave on loan today.
Ramsey is set to join

VFL Bochum
.

live_updates.title: Burnley sign Luis on season-long loan
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Burnley
have signed
Benfica
midfielder
Florentino Luis
on a season-long loan.
Deal includes option to make the deal permanent.
The 26-year-old has previously been on loan at Monaco and Getafe, but ended up making 181 appearances for his boyhood club across six seasons.

live_updates.title: Burnley sign Luis on season-long loan
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Burnley
have signed
Benfica
midfielder
Florentino Luis
on a season-long loan.
The deal includes an option to make the deal permanent.
The 26-year-old has previously been on loan at Monaco and Getafe, but ended up making 181 appearances for his boyhood club across six seasons.

live_updates.title: Ramsey joins Leicester on loan
live_updates.author: Charlotte Marsh
live_updates.text:
Aaron Ramsey
has joined
Leicester
on loan from
Burnley.
The 22-year-old will stay for the remainder of the season after two seasons with the Clarets.

live_updates.title: Free agent Brownhill agrees to join Saudi side Al Shabab after Burnley exit
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Exclusive from Sky Sports News' James Savundra:
Free agent
Josh Brownhill
has agreed to join Saudi Pro League club
Al Shabab
.
The former
Burnley
midfielder is set to sign a deal which will see him earn more than £ 100,000 per week.
Brownhill is due to travel to Saudi Arabia tomorrow to conduct a medical and wrap up the deal.
The 29-year-old rejected a fresh contract offer from Burnley and held talks with a number of Premier League clubs - including
Wolves
.
Brownhill was heavily sought after this summer, having fired Burnley back to the Premier League with 18 goals and six assists from midfield.

live_updates.title: Parker: 'Pleased with the start of the season'
live_updates.author: Sam Cohen
live_updates.text:
Burnley boss Scott Parker:
"
I’ve been pleased with the start of the season. Generally, I’ve been really happy with how we’ve played.
"We’ve been very competitive. We’ve had tough fixtures, coming off the back of a strong performance against United where we just missed out on a point in the dying moments. Overall, yeah, I’m pleased."

live_updates.title: Parker: Frustration at Old Trafford
live_updates.author: Sam Cohen
live_updates.text:
Burnley boss Scott Parker:
"I think there’s always a frustration when you’re that close [to a result at Old Trafford].
"The dynamics of the game and how it went - we got ourselves back into the game, then conceded the goal. The character we showed to get it to 2-2, then obviously in the dying minutes to concede a penalty and lose the game, there was a lot of frustration there."
"I said it after the game, I was mentally proud of the group. It’s a difficult place to go, and it was a new environment for a lot of the players as well. I thought we were a better version of ourselves than at points during the Tottenham match. But look, my frustration is out."

live_updates.title: Parker: Things need to go our way
live_updates.author: Sam Cohen
live_updates.text:
Burnley boss Scott Parker:
"We’re playing against an elite, world-class team, with numerous players in their squad having world-class talent. We understand the challenge.
"It’s a 90-minute game of football, and we will go and give the best version of ourselves. We are going to need a lot of things to go our way, we understand that - but we are relishing this opportunity, as we have done from the start of this season.
I think that’s been the main thing for us really, relishing these opportunities, going up against the best. And there’s no doubt we are going up against an extremely good team."

live_updates.title: Parker: All international players fit
live_updates.author: Sam Cohen
live_updates.text:
Burnley
boss
Scott Parker
has confirmed that there are no fresh injury concerns following the international break.
Speaking to the media, ahead of the Liverpool tie,
live on Sky Sports
, Parker said: "All players have come back fit and healthy from the international break. We are pretty solid."
Parker will be pleased to know his side won't be facing Curtis Jones, as he's been ruled out through injury.

live_updates.title: How do you beat Liverpool?
live_updates.author: Sam Cohen
live_updates.text:
Sky Sports' Sanny Rudravajhala:
It's the question 'every team is asking' Scott Parker told me, when I asked him ‘how do you beat Liverpool?’
Sunday will be arguably Burnley's toughest home game of the entire season. The reigning champions, with all their additions, which now includes Alexander Isak. Oof! The Burnley boss says they'll have to be the 'best version of themselves' for a chance against Arne Slot's side.
The Burnley manager also shared his thoughts on VAR after a late penalty call denied them a point at Old Trafford last time out in a 3-2 defeat. Parker's point on the emotion and how we may enjoy a game is one that will resonate with fans in a league that he admits has even changed since he was last in the Premier League with Bournemouth two years ago.
As for Turf Moor on Sunday, that's certainly been his happy place. Here's a remarkable stat for you: in his 25 home games in charge at Burnley, he's never experienced defeat. A record Clarets fans will be hoping, almost against hope, that they'll still have by Sunday evening.

live_updates.title: Parker on penalty: We need to train with hands behind our back
live_updates.author: Lewis Jones
live_updates.text:
Scott Parker
says he'll need to teach his players to defend crosses with their hands behind their back following Hannibal's handball that cost Burnley a point in their 1-0 defeat to Liverpool.
Former Manchester United midfielder Hannibal raised his hands needlessly in the area to block a cross in stoppage time, leaving referee Michael Oliver no choice but to point to the spot.
Parker said: "I came into this interview room not wanting to mention or not wanting to speak about the penalty decision. It's handball. In the law of it, it's handball.
"I know he's five yards away, and the hands outside the body in his arm. We'll have to probably change, and we are changing it. You're seeing a change of technique in defending now. You've got to put your arms behind your back to defend things.
"I know in desperation at certain moments. Like I said, this one today is your body action. He's turning. His arm's now gone out, and you see his arm. You see his arm from five yards, the ball coming at probably 80 miles an hour. Then it's hit it.
"The only learning from it for Hannibal is maybe we'll have to probably train with keeping your arms behind your back, which is a different technique to defending now but I think it's something we probably need to be aware of and certainly something we need to develop."

live_updates.title: Parker: My team epitomised spirit
live_updates.author: Lewis Jones
live_updates.text:
Scott Parker speaking to Sky Sports:
"At times, we survived like our life depended on it today and I think we knew we had to give that.
"I think the deciding factor for me is just everything we set out to be today. The players, I’m immensely proud of them, really. The game ends in a real heartbreaking way for us, but it is what it is.
"I'm someone who likes to take positives out of things and there was a lot of positives, certainly playing against this side today and we just fell a little bit short with the last minute.
"I think we knew what we needed to be, and I think you see that in certain moments of the game. You open the pitch up to this team, and they're probably one of the best in the world in terms of exploiting that.
"We were never going to give them that space. We needed to deny space, and it was critical for us. We did deny them space, and we defended very, very well.
"We're trying to get a result, and we're trying to survive.
"My team today, they epitomise spirit. They epitomise every bit of what I asked of them and that's exactly why I try and ingrain in these players every single day.
"I stood on that sideline immensely proud of this group. When they needed to dig, and when I say dig, that dig was practically 90 minutes.  We needed to survive in certain moments. Sometimes you need to search for places right deep somewhere and my players did that to a man."

live_updates.title: Was Ugochukwu red card fair?
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT
: Ugochukwu was then sent off late on for a second yellow after a lunge on Florian Wirtz
DERMOT SAYS: "
Why make a challenge like this? This will always be a second yellow card! That's what the rules are.
"Sometimes the referees have to do what they don't like."
BOTHROYD:
"I don't think he should be sent off for that. If that was his first challenge, then yes, it's a yellow card.
"But a second yellow? It's not enough. Wirtz has just come across his legs.
"I don't think that's a yellow card offence, in my opinion. I think that's really soft. Sometimes I want to see common sense."

live_updates.title: Should Ugochukwu have been sent off before his red card?
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT:
Lesley Ugochukwu was sent off for two yellow cards. His first came after 16 minutes, but could that have been a straight red for a tough challenge on Alexis Mac Allister.
DERMOT SAYS:
"I thought yellow at the time. It's a strong tackle. He gets a bit of the ball, but he does follow through. He catches him on the ankle, but he's low and comes from a short distance, so doesn't get any intensity."
JAY BOTHROYD:
"I keep hearing this whole thing about following through. Following through - what does that actually mean? You can't just lay down and do a tackle. You're going towards the ball. I look at that and just say that's a strong challenge. I don't say that's a straight red card.
"His foot's low, he's hit him on his ankle. When you look at his ankle, you'll say that's sore and is going to be painful, but ultimately, I wouldn't give a red card for that. He's innocently going for the ball. I don't think he followed through and tried to hurt the player.
"I think it's an honest attempt to go for the ball. Where's he meant to put his foot? The game goes at 100mph."

live_updates.title: Was Liverpool's late penalty correct?
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
INCIDENT:
Liverpool are given a late penalty after Hannibal Mejbri raised his arm in the penalty area to block Jeremie Frimpong's cross.
DERMOT SAYS:
"Definitely a penalty. He moves into the ball. His face showed exactly that he knew what he did."
BOTHROYD:
"Definitely a penalty. Hannibal should know better. No ifs or buts. There was no aggrievement from the Burnley players. "

live_updates.title: Burnley seeking Everton damages as court case begins
live_updates.author: Callum Bishop
live_updates.text:
Latest from Sky Sports News' Amar Mehta and Kaveh Solhekol:
A dispute between
Burnley
and
Everton
has started in a London court.
Burnley   are seeking damages of £50m from Everton after the Merseyside club  were  found guilty of breaching PSR rules in the 2021/22 season.
In   November 2023 Everton were deducted 10 points, reduced to six on   appeal, for breaking Premier League Profitability and Sustainability   Rules over a three-year period.
Burnley  were relegated to the  Championship in 2021/22 and claim that if  Everton's points deduction  had been enforced that year they would have  stayed up.
Burnley   went down after finishing four points below Everton and allege that   this led to losses in revenue, sponsorship and TV money.
Premier   League rules were changed following Everton's points deduction   which meant any PSR breaches would be investigated in the same   season.
Burnley and Everton have declined to comment.

live_updates.title: Parker: Anthony is fundamental to us
live_updates.author: William Bitibiri
live_updates.text:
Burnley
boss
Scott Parker
says forward
Jaidon Anthony
is key to his side after his role in the Clarets' 1-1 draw with
Nottingham Forest
.
Anthony cancelled out Neco Williams' opening goal as Burnley held Forest at Turf Moor. The 25-year-old scored his third goal of the season, having scored in all but two of Burnley's league games this season.
Asked about the wide player that he worked with previously at Bournemouth, Parker said:
"Jaidon [Anthony] is [key to us]. I'm familiar with Jaidon and have had large experience with him.
"I'm pleased for him. He's got huge quality. At this moment, he's been fundamental to us in terms of the attacking phase of our game.
"I'm pleased again that he gets on the score sheet. Confidence is sky high for him."

live_updates.title: Burnley have shown they belong in the Premier League, says Laurent
live_updates.author: Oliver Yew
live_updates.text:
Josh Laurent
believes
Burnley
are proving they belong in the Premier League.
The Clarets made it four points from their opening five games with a 1-1 draw against Nottingham Forest at Turf Moor on Saturday.
Burnley have twice bounced back from relegation at the first time of asking but lasted only one season in the Premier League two years ago.
They were well beaten by Tottenham in their opening game this time but have impressed since, defeating Sunderland and losing narrowly to Manchester United and Liverpool.
They went behind after less than two minutes against Forest but responded well and might have had more to show for their efforts than Jaidon Anthony’s equaliser.
Laurent, who again dropped back into defence, said: “I think it’s a very good performance with and without the ball, I think we showed both sides of our game.
“It’s a bit more of a complete performance than probably we’ve shown so far. We keep improving and showing a bit more each week, so there’s so much more to come from his team and this club.
“Of course, you want to pick up points, we all know we have to pick up points to be successful in this league. We wanted three, we really wanted to put a stamp down again.
“Next week’s another tough test but we go there again looking to get three points. I think every week we’ve shown that we belong here and that we can really do something special this year together.
“I think we’ve got better each week. The first game, we were in the game, it wasn’t a 3-0 I would say, but we probably deserved to lose overall. Since then, I don’t think we really deserved to lose again.”

live_updates.title: Parker admits Burnley were ‘well short’ after shock cup loss to Cardiff
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Burnley
manager
Scott Parker
defended his decision to make wholesale changes for the Carabao Cup tie against
Cardiff
after watching his Premier League side crash out at the third-round stage following a 2-1 home defeat.
Parker, who made 11 changes, said: “The feeling is disappointment. We wanted to get a result and keep us in the cup but that hasn’t happened.
“I’m also disappointed with the performance. We were well short of where we needed to be. There were some tactical things we were short on but lots of others – intensity, duels and being sloppy on the ball.
“We gave ourselves a mountain to climb. We had some really good chances to come back into it but didn’t take them.
“It would be unfair of me, though, to say we’d have deserved it on this occasion.
“The fundamentals weren’t there. You need the foundations and then you can start layering it.
“I don’t think there was a lack of willingness. But we weren’t at it.
“There’s a big squad here and we need to give them minutes. They are going to be used during the season because of injuries and such like.
“Full credit to Cardiff.”

live_updates.title: Parker: Tough run will stand us in good stead
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Scott Parker
believes
Burnley’s
tough run of fixtures will stand them in good stead for the rest of the season.
The Clarets were welcomed back to the Premier League with a sequence of matches that included clashes with Tottenham, Manchester United, Liverpool and now Manchester City in their first six games.
Burnley have proved very competitive so far, with last weekend’s draw against Nottingham Forest taking them to four points, and Parker has been delighted with how his players have reacted to the steep learning curve.
“I’ve seen that already because we have faced some problems,” he said. “Old Trafford only two weeks ago, the first 30 minutes, the scoreline could have been drastic. We managed to survive in that moment and then we have something about us to get ourselves back in the game.
“This team lost two football matches last year so there’s always learning for me: what’s our reaction going to be like when we go and lose a game or we go down in a game? Last year this team were constantly showing me traits which are, we’ll be all right.”
Fixtures do not come much tougher than a trip to the Etihad Stadium, and Parker added: “For sure we’ve got a big challenge ahead of us but in this early part of the season, five games down, we’ve come through that and that fills me with big confidence.”
Kyle Walker
goes back to City, while goalkeeper
James Trafford
, who is likely to be on the bench for Pep Guardiola’s team, was a key figure in Burnley’s promotion from the Championship last season.
Trafford has been usurped by fellow summer signing
Gianluigi Donnarumma
, and Parker said: “It’s a shame, I suppose, but he’s at an absolutely massive football club and the competition there is absolutely huge.
“I can’t wait to see him, an incredible goalie. He was brilliant to be around and brilliant for me to coach.”

live_updates.title: Parker backs Walker for England return
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Scott Parker
has backed
Kyle Walker
to return to the England squad.
Walker is only four short of a century of caps for his country, with his last appearance coming in June's friendly against Senegal, but he was not named in
Thomas Tuchel
's most recent squad.
Asked if he can catch Tuchel's eye at Burnley, Parker said: "He definitely can. His last performance for us, he was the best out there, I thought he was absolutely immense.
"He's playing in a different way now and there's a different side to his game which is going to be tested a lot more than it's ever been but, when you're at the level he's at, it's not a problem for him. I have no doubt he can force his way and be in and around the England squad.
"He's been massive for us, his experience and his quality as well. We always seem to revert back to Kyle and we speak about his experience but I think his quality is something that we've all seen in a short period of time.
"The biggest compliment I can pay to Kyle is his reaction to the different environment, different way of playing at times with us than what he's probably been used to.
"I had absolutely no doubt bringing Kyle in here that he'd embrace every bit of that and he has done that. I've never seen a frustration, in fact I've seen a really positive encouragement and wanting to support and help, and that's what I'm pleased with the most."
Walker will make his first return to face old club
Manchester City
at the Etihad Stadium on Saturday, with Burnley looking to build on last weekend's draw with Nottingham Forest.

live_updates.title: Pep: Walker among best full-backs ever
live_updates.author: Ron Walker
live_updates.text:
Pep Guardiola
heaped praise on former
Man City
right-back
Kyle Walker
ahead of the pair's first reunion when his new side
Burnley
visit the Etihad on Saturday.
Walker left the club in the summer after eight years in Manchester, joining the club at the end of Guardiola's first season - long enough to receive medals from all 15 major honours won under the current boss.
The 35-year-old fell out of favour in his final season at the club and spent the second half of the campaign on loan at AC Milan before joining Burnley.
But Guardiola said he still remembers England defender as one of the game's all-time greats in his position.
"I'm pretty sure everybody will be happy to see him," he said.
"It was an unbelievable few years for us and he was the right-back who defined our time here in the last nine or 10 years. I'm pretty sure he will get the gratitude of our fans.
"Absolutely he deserves it. [He is] one of the greatest full-backs ever. In terms of his consistency, no injuries, an incredible figure in the dressing room.
"In eight years, six Premier Leagues, a Champions League, always being there in the good moments and the bad moments.
"Of course, the last season was tough for everyone, for him and all of us, but I don't want to judge one behaviour for a short period of time. He was unbelievable.
"When you have to control that side with a winger, I slept like a baby before a game with Kyle there. He can handle top-class wingers, he could handle it.
"He was a better player on the ball than maybe he could think. My target when he came in was to tell him that. The quality of his long balls, his passing - an incredible right-back for us."

live_updates.title: Parker: We played very, very well today despite 5-1 loss
live_updates.author: Sam Blitz
live_updates.text:
Burnley head coach Scott Parker to Sky Sports:
"Performance-wise, I was with us delighted for 60 to 70 minutes. They showed every bit from what I wanted us from this game. We were right in the game, of course you're up against a colossus club with world class talent. We had to suffer at times, but we also needed to be brave and courageous today and showed our quality, we did that for a large part of it.
"Two goals come back to back that put a massive dent in us and the game goes away from us a bit. I don't think the scoreline really reflects that, there were massive positives for us from the first part of that game.
"My feeling watching that game, looking at my team, is we played very, very well. The back end there are bits that are disappointing. I understand that, because you're playing against a team where the game can quickly move away from you.
"You can come to Man City and get beat comfortably, I've seen world class teams have those problems. We take the positives from today and understand the moments we can improve, we keep going."

live_updates.title: Free agent Brownhill agrees to join Saudi side Al Shabab after Burnley exit
live_updates.author: Declan Olley
live_updates.text:
Exclusive from Sky Sports News' James Savundra:
Free agent
Josh Brownhill
has agreed to join Saudi Pro League club
Al Shabab
.
The former
Burnley
midfielder is set to sign a deal which will see him earn more than £ 100,000 per week.
Brownhill is due to travel to Saudi Arabia tomorrow to conduct a medical and wrap up the deal.
The 29-year-old rejected a fresh contract offer from Burnley and held talks with a number of Premier League clubs - including
Wolves
.
Brownhill was heavily sought after this summer, having fired Burnley back to the Premier League with 18 goals and six assists from midfield.
